Text: O LORD, our Lord, how majestic is Your name in all the earth! You have set Your glory above the heavens.
Context: This is the opening praise, establishing the theme of God’s majesty and glory which is apparent throughout creation.

Text: From the mouths of infants and nursing babes You have ordained praise on account of Your adversaries, to silence the enemy and avenger.
Context: This verse reflects the power of God, who can establish strength and praise even from the seemingly weakest beings, overcoming opposition.

Text: When I consider Your heavens, the work of Your fingers, the moon and the stars, which You have set in place—
Context: The psalmist expresses amazement at the vastness of God’s creation, acknowledging the celestial bodies as the work of God’s own fingers.

Text: what is man that You are mindful of him, the son of man that You care for him?
Context: This is a rhetorical question reflecting humility, pondering why such a transcendent God would pay attention to humanity.

Text: You have made him a little lower than the angels and crowned him with glory and honor.
Context: The psalmist acknowledges the high status of humans in creation, being made only slightly lower than the heavenly beings.

Text: You made him ruler over the works of Your hands; You put everything under his feet:
Context: The verse describes the God-given dominion and responsibility of humans to steward the creation.

Text: all flocks and herds, and the beasts of the field,
Context: The specifics of human dominion over various categories of animals begins here.

Text: the birds of the air, and the fish of the sea, all that swim the paths of the seas.
Context: Continues the list of living creatures over which humans have been given stewardship.

Text: O LORD, our Lord, how majestic is Your name in all the earth!
Context: The psalm concludes as it began, with a powerful affirmation of God's majesty manifest in all the earth.
